Congress must pass my Facial Recognition and Biometrics Moratorium Act and stop the dangerous proliferation of this technology.

It's clear‚Äîbiometric tools pose a very tangible, personal threat to our civil liberties. They are making it increasingly difficult for us to move, appear, and congregate in public without being tracked.
In 2022, Alonzo Sawyer, a Black man from Maryland, was falsely identified and arrested for assaulting a bus driver and stealing her phone. He spent nine days in prison.

In 2019, Nijeer Parks spent 10 days in jail after law enforcement‚Äôs facial recognition software had falsely identified him as a man who shoplifted candy and attempted to hit a police officer with his car.
Companies like Clearview are reportedly allowing more than 1,000 law enforcement agencies to upload photos of unidentified faces and scan the internet for images matching their likeness.

Last I checked, 1984 was a work of fiction. But right now many government agencies are using facial rec, and false arrests of Black men have continued‚Äîripping innocent people away from their families and locking them in jail. It's unacceptable.

Their stories are a powerful reminder of the challenges women face across the globe - for bodily autonomy, dignity, and basic human rights.

These egregious violations by the CCP must be condemned and the world must hear these women‚Äôs powerful stories. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqtS0B1WYAMA0O5.jpg

The women I spoke to had to have corrective surgery when they arrived in the United States to fix the harm done by the botched, forced sterilizations.

They have had to leave family members behind, many in camps, to an uncertain fate.

Finally, they told me that the only reason they are free today is because their husbands were all dual citizens who could advocate for their release from safe countries.

But they still carry the scars of their time there.

And when they tried to speak out, they received threats against their family. One of the women learned that her family members had been taken to a camp as a consequence of her choice to speak up.

They told her, "if you stop, they will be released."

But one of them was killed.

But the worst came when they were sent to the Uyghur internment camps.

There, they shared with me the trauma of being forcibly sterilized, "like animals," with no regard for their health or bodily autonomy.

Even their cemeteries were not safe. 

The CCP ordered families to disinter their relatives and move them to assigned plots - many so small that the bones of their loved ones would need to be broken to fit.

Around their villages, they had to carry booklets where, if they angered a Communist Party guard, they would receive demerits. 

Too many demerits, and you were sent to the camps.

At their homes, CCP officials were placed to monitor their behavior and report on them if they practiced their religion. 

Every day, they faced the threat of being sent to internment camps for their beliefs.

They told me that it started slowly. One of them had a third child, in violation of Chinese law. So they were given a fine of over US $2,500.

But from there, it escalated.

Yesterday, I heard powerful testimony from a group of women, whose stories I want to share with you this #InternationalWomensDay.

They are Uyghurs, from the Xinjiang province of China. And they are survivors of the Uyghur internment camps run by the Chinese Communist Party. üßµ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqtSxw7X0AQrStV.jpg

‚ÄúI want every gold and blue star family member, and every veteran out there watching this to know: I will not rest until we determine how this happened ‚Äì and hold those responsible for it accountable.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause even though President Biden said, and I quote, ‚Äòif there‚Äôs American citizens left, we‚Äôre gonna stay to get them all out.‚Äô ‚Äì we now know he left more than 1,000 American citizens in Afghanistan.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat happened in Afghanistan was a systemic breakdown of the federal government at every level ‚Äì and a stunning failure of leadership by the Biden administration.‚Äù

‚ÄúThankfully ‚Äì in the void left by an absent State Department ‚Äì many Americans stepped up to fill the vacuum. Primarily organized by veterans, groups like Allied Airlift 21, Team America, and Task Force Pineapple ‚Äì just to name a few ‚Äì saved thousands of lives.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn the midst of the unfolding chaos in Kabul in August 2021, the U.S. State Department was all but useless.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are joined today by Marine Sergeant Tyler Vargas-Andrews and former Army Specialist Aidan Gunderson. Both were deployed to Afghanistan during the evacuation. They can give a first-hand account of what it was like inside the Kabul airport during those harrowing two weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd then, horror struck on August 26th. A suicide bomber at Abbey Gate killed 13 American servicemembers, injured at least 45 more, and killed approximately 170 Afghans. That day was the deadliest day for American troops in Afghanistan in 10 years."

‚ÄúDesperate Afghans, clinging to planes as they took off ‚Äì with some plummeting from the sky to their deaths. Mothers handing their children to strangers over the airport walls ‚Äì willingly giving them up in the hopes of saving their lives."

"Because of the Biden administration's dereliction of duty, the world watched heartbreaking scenes unfold in & around the Kabul airport for the next two weeks. A sea of humanity, desperately trying to make it through airport gates that represented freedom."
‚ÄúAs a result, when the Taliban rapidly captured territory during the summer of 2021 and entered Kabul on August 15th ‚Äì we simply weren‚Äôt ready.‚Äù
‚ÄúMultiple people in the Biden administration said they had planned for every contingency. They did not. Instead, they spent the next four months kicking the can down the road.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe president promised, quote, ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs going to be no circumstances where you see people being lifted off the roof of an embassy.‚Äô [There] were.‚Äù

Congress must pass my Facial Recognition and Biometric Technology Moratorium Act and stop the dangerous proliferation of this technology.

It's clear‚Äîbiometric tools pose a very tangible, personal threat to our civil liberties. They are making it increasingly difficult for us to move, appear, and congregate in public without being tracked.
In 2022, Alonzo Sawyer, a Black man from Maryland, was falsely identified and arrested for assaulting a bus driver and stealing her phone. He spent nine days in prison.

In 2019, Nijeer Parks spent 10 days in jail after law enforcement‚Äôs facial recognition software had falsely identified him as a man who shoplifted candy and attempted to hit a police officer with his car.
Companies like Clearview are reportedly allowing more than 1,000 law enforcement agencies to upload photos of unidentified faces and scan the internet for images matching their likeness.

Last I checked, 1984 was a work of fiction. But right now many government agencies are using facial rec, and false arrests of Black men have continued‚Äîripping innocent people away from their families and locking them in jail. It's unacceptable.

Facial recognition enables discrimination and poses serious threats to privacy and justice. I want to thank @RepKamlagerDove for joining me in this effort and sponsoring this critical legislation. 

Find more information on the Preparing Superfund for Climate Change Act here:
https://cleaver.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/reps-cleaver-kamlager-dove-introduce-bill-protect-communities-superfund

As we saw in East Palestine, when the government fails to put precautions in place and implement needed safety standards, communities bear the brunt of a disaster.

Let‚Äôs prepare BEFORE a disaster occurs, so that we can keep families safe.

My bill would help protect communities near Superfund sites by requiring the @EPA to account for climate change in their plans for safely managing these sites, including potential cleanup plans.

It also calls for periodic reviews to determine if plans are adequately protective.

As climate change makes natural disasters more frequent and more acute, the risk of catastrophe only increases if we fail to prepare‚Äîand with 39 Superfund sites in Missouri, that's a risk we have to address.

That‚Äôs where my Preparing Superfund for Climate Change Act comes in.

In 2019, @USGAO released a report concluding Superfund sites across America are severely underprepared to weather the exacerbating threat of climate change, risking calamity in the surrounding communities.

Find that report here:
https://www.gao.gov/products/gao-20-73

Right now, throughout the U.S. there are thousands of Superfund sites‚Äîwhich are polluted locations that contain hazardous toxic waste & other contaminants harmful to public health.

And many of them are vulnerable to flooding, storm surge, wildfires, and other natural disasters.

Americans would be shocked to learn how many Superfund sites in the US are vulnerable to natural disasters that are becoming more frequent due to climate change.

To protect our communities from toxic waste at these sites, I wrote the Preparing Superfund for Climate Change Act. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FquCcfvWYCop4rn.png
